title: Turn Off the Furnace
description: Switch your furnace to the OFF position or turn off the power at the circuit breaker.
pro_tip: Wait 30 seconds after turning off to let any residual airflow stop.

title: Check the Thermostat
description: Ensure the thermostat is set to HEAT mode and the set temperature is above the current room temperature.
pro_tip: Bump the temperature up 5 degrees above room temp to force the call.

title: Turn Off the AC Unit
description: Switch off at thermostat and disconnect switch near the outdoor unit.

title: Turn Off the AC
description: Turn off at the thermostat and breaker.

title: Check Compatibility
description: Verify your system is compatible. Most smart thermostats require a C-wire.
pro_tip: Use online compatibility checkers. Photo your current wiring first.

title: Replace the Air Filter
description: Check monthly, replace every 1-3 months.
pro_tip: Buy filters in bulk to always have replacements.

title: Identify Leaks
description: Turn on the fan and feel for air escaping at joints. Use tissue to detect fluttering.
pro_tip: Focus on ducts closest to the air handler where pressure is highest.

title: Turn Off the Fan
description: Switch off at the wall switch. For safety, turn off the circuit breaker too.

title: Locate the Filter Compartment
description: Find the filter slot between the return air duct and the blower compartment.
pro_tip: Take a photo of the current filter orientation before removing it.

title: Verify the Gas Supply
description: Check that the gas valve near the furnace is ON (handle parallel to the pipe).
pro_tip: If you smell gas strongly, leave immediately and call your gas company.

title: Remove Debris
description: Clear leaves, grass clippings, and debris. Maintain at least 2 feet of clearance.
pro_tip: Trim back bushes or plants that have grown too close.

title: Locate the Drain Line
description: Find the PVC condensate drain line near the indoor air handler.
pro_tip: Place towels around the drain pan if there is standing water.

title: Turn Off HVAC Power
description: Turn off power at the circuit breaker.

title: Clean the Outdoor Unit
description: Remove debris and hose down coil fins. Maintain 2 feet of clearance.
pro_tip: In winter, gently remove ice — let the defrost cycle handle most of it.

title: Gather Materials
description: Get mastic sealant or metal-backed UL 181 tape. Avoid standard duct tape.
pro_tip: Mastic is the best long-term solution — apply with a paintbrush.

title: Remove the Cover
description: Pull the cover down and squeeze spring clips to release. Some models use screws.
pro_tip: Place a towel below to catch falling dust.

title: Remove the Old Filter
description: Carefully slide the old filter out. Note the size printed on the frame (e.g., 16x25x1) and the airflow arrow.

title: Inspect the Air Filter
description: A severely clogged filter can cause overheating and shutdown. Replace if dirty.

title: Remove the Fan Guard
description: Unscrew the top fan guard/grille. Lift the fan assembly out carefully.

title: Clear with Vinegar
description: Pour 1 cup distilled white vinegar into the drain access point. Let sit 30 minutes.
pro_tip: For stubborn clogs, use a wet/dry vacuum on the outdoor end.

title: Remove the Old Thermostat
description: Remove faceplate and label each wire with its terminal letter (R, W, Y, G, C).
pro_tip: Wrap tape around each wire and write the terminal letter on it.

title: Check Refrigerant Lines
description: Inspect insulation on lines between indoor and outdoor units. Replace if damaged.
pro_tip: Black foam insulation tape is inexpensive and easy to apply.

title: Clean Surfaces
description: Wipe the area around each leak with a damp cloth for proper adhesion.

title: Clean Cover and Blades
description: Wash the cover in warm soapy water. Vacuum dust from fan blades and motor housing.
pro_tip: Compressed air works great for hard-to-reach motor dust.

title: Insert the New Filter
description: Slide the new filter in with the airflow arrow pointing toward the blower. Ensure a snug fit.
pro_tip: Write the installation date on the filter frame with a marker.

title: Check the Igniter
description: Open the access panel and inspect the hot surface igniter for visible cracks or breaks.
pro_tip: Handle the igniter carefully — the ceramic element is very fragile.

title: Clean the Coil Fins
description: Spray fins from inside out with a garden hose (NOT a pressure washer). Use coil cleaner for stubborn buildup.
pro_tip: Always spray from inside out to push dirt outward.

title: Flush with Water
description: Flush the line with warm water. Check the outdoor exit for free flow.
pro_tip: Pour vinegar monthly during cooling season to prevent clogs.

title: Install the New Base Plate
description: Mount the new base plate using a level. Mark and drill screw holes.
pro_tip: Measure if the new plate covers the old mounting mark.

title: Clean Indoor Coil and Drain
description: Clean the evaporator coil with a soft brush. Flush the condensate drain with vinegar.

title: Apply Sealant
description: Apply mastic generously over joints, extending 1 inch beyond seams. Use mesh tape for larger gaps.
pro_tip: Let mastic dry 24 hours before running the system.

title: Reinstall and Test
description: Reattach the cover, restore power, and test — the fan should spin freely and quietly.
pro_tip: Clean exhaust fans every 6 months for optimal performance.

title: Restore Power and Test
description: Turn the furnace back on and set the thermostat to call for heat. Verify air flows through the vents.
pro_tip: Set a reminder to check your filter every 30 days.

title: Reset the Furnace
description: Turn off the power for 30 seconds, then turn it back on to reset the control board.
pro_tip: Note any blinking LED codes on the control board — they indicate specific errors.

title: Straighten Bent Fins
description: Use a fin comb or butter knife to gently straighten bent aluminum fins.
pro_tip: Be gentle — the fins are thin and can break easily.

title: Connect the Wires
description: Connect each labeled wire to its corresponding terminal.
pro_tip: If no C-wire, some thermostats include a power extender kit.

title: Test Both Modes
description: Test heating and cooling modes during seasonal changeover.
pro_tip: Listen for unusual sounds indicating failing components.

title: Insulate Ducts
description: Wrap ducts in unconditioned spaces with R-6 or R-8 insulation.
pro_tip: Insulating attic ducts can reduce energy loss by 10-15%.

title: Check the Flame Sensor
description: If the furnace ignites but shuts off quickly, clean the flame sensor with fine sandpaper.
pro_tip: A dirty flame sensor is one of the most common and cheapest furnace fixes.

title: Reassemble and Test
description: Replace the fan guard, restore power, and set thermostat to cool.
pro_tip: Do this at the start of every cooling season.

title: Configure
description: Snap on the display, restore power, and follow the setup wizard for WiFi and scheduling.
pro_tip: Enable learning/adaptive features for automatic optimization.
